IBIO150.name: Integrating Biology: From DNA to Populations
IBIO150.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
IBIO150.description: Examine biological systems across multiple levels of organization - spatial, temporal, taxonomic - using evolutionary biology as the common thread.
IBIO150.prerequisite: ((MTH 103 or concurrently) or (MTH 110 or concurrently) or (MTH 112 or concurrently) or (MTH 116 or concurrently) or (MTH 124 or concurrently) or (MTH 132 or concurrently) or (LB 118 or concurrently) or (MTH 201 or concurrently) or (STT 200 or concurrently) or (STT 201 or concurrently)) or designated score on Mathematics Placement test
IBIO150.restrictions: Not open to undergraduate students in the Department of Integrative Biology.

IBIO162.name: Organismal and Population Biology
IBIO162.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
IBIO162.description: Biological diversity and organismal biology. Principles of evolution, transmission genetics, population biology, community structure, ecology.

IBIO172.name: Organismal and Population Biology Laboratory
IBIO172.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
IBIO172.description: Nature and process of organismal biology including experimental design, statistical methods, hypothesis testing in genetics, ecology, and evolution.

IBIO182H.name: Honors Organismal and Population Biology
IBIO182H.description: Diversity and basic properties of organisms, with emphasis on genetic principles, ecological interactions, and the evolutionary process. Historical approach to knowledge discovery.

IBIO192H.name: Honors Organismal and Population Biology Laboratory
IBIO192H.description: Nature and process of organismal biology, including experimental design and statistical methods, hypothesis testing, genetics, ecology, and evolution.

IBIO200.name: Animal Biodiversity
IBIO200.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
IBIO200.description: Importance of animal biodiversity in the context of evolution, ecology, conservation, and resource use.
IBIO200.restrictions: Open to students in the Integrative Biology major.

IBIO300.name: Neurobiology
IBIO300.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
IBIO300.description: Structure and function of nerve cells and nervous systems.
IBIO300.prerequisite: (BS 162 or LB 144 or BS 182H) and (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H)
IBIO300.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores and not open to students in the Program in Neuroscience and not open to students in the Lyman Briggs Neuroscience Major.

IBIO303.name: Oceanography
IBIO303.description: Physical, chemical, biological, and geological aspects of oceanography
IBIO303.prerequisite: (CEM 141 or CEM 181H or LB 171 or CEM 151) and (PHY 231 or PHY 183 or PHY 193H or LB 273 or PHY 183B or PHY 231C or PHY 241)

IBIO306.name: Invertebrate Biology
IBIO306.description: Systematics, morphology, and natural history of invertebrate animals. Identification of live and preserved specimens. Recognition of selected groups.

IBIO310.name: Psychology and Biology of Human Sexuality
IBIO310.description: Sexual behavior from biological, psychological and neuroscience perspectives. Sexual differentiation of the body. Role of hormones in development and reproduction in humans and other animals. Human sexual orientation. Fertility and contraception. Sexual disorders. Sexually transmitted diseases.
IBIO310.prerequisite: (PSY 101 or concurrently) and ((BS 161 or concurrently) or (BS 162 or concurrently) or (LB 144 or concurrently) or (LB 145 or concurrently) or (BS 181H or concurrently) or (BS 182H or concurrently))

IBIO313.name: Animal Behavior
IBIO313.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
IBIO313.description: Development, physiological mediation, adaptive significance and evolution of behavior.

IBIO319.name: Introduction to Earth System Science
IBIO319.description: Systems approach to Earth as an integration of geochemical, geophysical, biological and social components. Global dynamics at a variety of spatio-temporal scales. Sustainability of the Earth system.

IBIO320.name: Developmental Biology
IBIO320.description: Principles of development, emphasizing vertebrates. Illustrations from morphological and experimental investigations.
IBIO320.prerequisite: (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H) and (BS 162 or LB 144 or BS 182H)

IBIO328.name: Comparative Anatomy and Biology of Vertebrates
IBIO328.description: Comparative morphology, evolution and biodiversity of vertebrates. Dissection of representatives of most vertebrate classes.

IBIO341.name: Fundamental Genetics
IBIO341.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
IBIO341.description: Principles of heredity in animals, plants and microorganisms. Classical and molecular methods in the study of gene structure, transmission, expression and evolution.
IBIO341.prerequisite: (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H) and (BS 162 or LB 144 or BS 182H)

IBIO353.name: Marine Biology (W)
IBIO353.description: Analysis of marine and estuarine systems. Integration of biology, chemistry, and physics. Life histories of marine organisms. Biology of special marine habitats including rocky intertidal zones, upwellings, coral reefs and deep sea.
IBIO353.prerequisite: (BS 162 or LB 144 or BS 182H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

IBIO355.name: Ecology
IBIO355.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
IBIO355.description: Interrelationships of plants and animals with each other and the environment. Principles of individual, population, community, and ecosystem ecology. Application of ecological principles to global change and other anthropogenic stressors.

IBIO355L.name: Ecology Laboratory (W)
IBIO355L.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
IBIO355L.description: Population, community, and ecosystem ecology, utilizing plant and animal examples to demonstrate general field principles.
IBIO355L.prerequisite: (IBIO 355 or concurrently) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

IBIO357.name: Global Change Biology (W)
IBIO357.description: Causes and consequences of modes of contemporary global change that are caused by biological systems or impact biological systems. Theories, evidence, and predictions in global warming, ocean acidification, desertification, eutrophication, food security, and mass extinction.
IBIO357.prerequisite: (IBIO 355) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

IBIO358.name: Streams to Gulf: Environmental Change in America's Deep South
IBIO358.description: A study away course of anthropogenic impacts, habitat alteration, and environmental policy in surrounding water.

IBIO360.name: Biology of Birds
IBIO360.description: Behavior, ecology, evolution, and systematics of birds; biodiversity. Laboratories emphasize diversity of form and function, life history patterns, and identification.

IBIO365.name: Biology of Mammals
IBIO365.description: Analysis of the behavior, ecology, evolution, and systematics of mammals. Laboratories emphasize diversity of form and function, life history patterns, and identification.

IBIO368.name: Zoo Animal Biology and Conservation
IBIO368.description: Captive animal biology including illustrated examples of care, behavioral welfare and conservation work.
IBIO368.prerequisite: BS 162 or LB 144 or BS 182H or approval of department

IBIO369.name: Introduction to Zoo and Aquarium Science
IBIO369.description: Fundamentals of zoo and aquarium operations including research, interpretation, design, nutrition, captive breeding, conservation, ethics and management.

IBIO370.name: Introduction to Zoogeography
IBIO370.description: Patterns of geographical distribution of animals and the ecological and historical processes leading to these patterns.

IBIO384.name: Biology of Amphibians and Reptiles (W)
IBIO384.description: The evolution, systematics, ecology, and behavior of amphibians and reptiles. Laboratory emphasizes diversity and identification of families and Great Lakes species. Field trips may be required.
IBIO384.prerequisite: (BS 162 or LB 144 or BS 182H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

IBIO390.name: Practicum in Zoo/Aquarium Careers
IBIO390.description: Practical application of science, business and education methods through typical workdays with zoo professionals.

IBIO391.name: Emerging Scholars in Integrative Biology
IBIO391.description: Professional development topics aimed at preparing for participating in research and beyond, the scientific method, research methods, and communication in science.

IBIO400H.name: Honors Work
IBIO400H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
IBIO400H.description: Honors work on a topic in zoology.
IBIO400H.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

IBIO405.name: Neural Basis of Animal Behavior
IBIO405.description: Structure and function of neurons and neural circuits underlying naturally-occurring animal behaviors.
IBIO405.prerequisite: (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H) and (BS 162 or LB 144 or BS 182H)

IBIO408.name: Histology
IBIO408.description: Structure of cells and their interactions to form tissues.

IBIO413.name: Laboratory in Behavioral Neuroscience (W)
IBIO413.description: Theory and laboratory experience in the study of behavioral neuroscience. Relationship among hormones, brain, and behavior.
IBIO413.prerequisite: (PSY 209 or IBIO 402) and ((PSY 295 or STT 231) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

IBIO415.name: Ecological Aspects of Animal Behavior (W)
IBIO415.description: Advanced topics in the ecology and evolution of animal behavior.
IBIO415.prerequisite: (IBIO 313) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

IBIO416.name: Development of the Nervous System Through the Lifespan
IBIO416.description: Development of neurons and their connections, roles of both genetics and behavioral experience in shaping the mammalian nervous system.
IBIO416.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Program in Neuroscience or in the Department of Integrative Biology or in the Department of Psychology or in the Lyman Briggs Neuroscience Major or in the Lyman Briggs Zoology Coordinate Major.

IBIO420.name: Stream Ecology
IBIO420.description: Biological and environmental factors determining structure and function of stream ecosystems.

IBIO422.name: Aquatic Entomology
IBIO422.description: Biology, ecology and systematics of aquatic insects in streams, rivers and lakes. Field trips and aquatic insect collection required.

IBIO424.name: Algal Biology
IBIO424.semester: Fall of even years, Summer of odd years
IBIO424.description: Algal taxonomy, systematics, physiology, ecology, and environmental assessment. Lab focus on identification of freshwater algal genera collected from regional habitats.
IBIO424.prerequisite: (BS 162 or LB 144 or BS 182H) and ((BS 172 or BS 192H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

IBIO425.name: Cells and Development (W)
IBIO425.description: The role of cells in growth, differentiation and development of animals from protozoa to mammals.
IBIO425.prerequisite: (BS 161 and BS 171) or LB 145 or ((BS 181H and BS 191H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

IBIO433.name: Vertebrate Paleontology
IBIO433.description: Fossil vertebrates with emphasis on evolution and interrelationships of major groups. Modern techniques of identification and interpretation of fossils.
IBIO433.prerequisite: IBIO 328 or GLG 304 or IBIO 360 or IBIO 365 or IBIO 384 or IBIO 445 or GLG 434 or FW 471

IBIO434.name: Evolutionary Paleobiology
IBIO434.description: Patterns and processes of evolution known from the fossil record

IBIO435.name: Ion Channels of Excitable Membranes
IBIO435.description: Introduction to ion channels and their critical role in normal physiological functioning, sensory and neuromuscular diseases and disorders, as well as targets of toxins and poisons.
IBIO435.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Neuroscience Major or in the Bachelor of Science in Zoology or in the Lyman Briggs Neuroscience Major or in the Lyman Briggs Zoology Coordinate Major.

IBIO440.name: Field Ecology and Evolution
IBIO440.description: Solving conceptual and practical research problems in ecology and evolution under field conditions.

IBIO443.name: Restoration Ecology
IBIO443.description: Principles of ecological restoration of disturbed or damaged ecosystems. Design, implementation, and presentation of restoration plans. Field trips required.

IBIO444.name: Conservation Biology
IBIO444.description: Ecological theories and methodologies to manage species, communities and genetic diversity on a local and global scale.
IBIO444.prerequisite: (IBIO 355 or FOR 404 or PLB 441) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

IBIO445.name: Evolution (W)
IBIO445.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
IBIO445.description: Processes of evolutionary change in animals, plants. Microbes. Population genetics, microevolution, speciation, adaptive radiation, macroevolution. Origin of Homo sapiens.
IBIO445.prerequisite: (IBIO 341 or CSS 350) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

IBIO446.name: Environmental Issues and Public Policy
IBIO446.description: Interrelationship of science and public policy in resolving environmental issues. Technical, social, economic, and legal influences. Case study approach.
IBIO446.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

IBIO450.name: Cancer Biology (W)
IBIO450.prerequisite: (BMB 200 or BMB 401 or IBIO 425) or ((BMB 461 and BMB 462) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

IBIO451.name: Insect Physiology
IBIO451.description: Structure/function of insect physiological systems. Molecular mechanisms underlying insect development. Physiological evolution in insects.

IBIO471.name: Ichthyology
IBIO471.description: Fish morphology and physiology. Development, behavior, evolution, and ecology. World fishes with emphasis on freshwater fishes. Field trips required.
IBIO471.prerequisite: {(BS 162 and BS 172) or (BS 182H and BS 192H) or LB 144} and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

IBIO472.name: Limnology
IBIO472.description: Ecology of lakes with emphasis on interacting physical, chemical, and biological factors affecting their structure and function.

IBIO474.name: Field and Laboratory Techniques for Aquatic Studies
IBIO474.description: Field and laboratory techniques for the investigation and analysis of lake and stream ecosystems and their biota. Field trips required.
IBIO474.prerequisite: (FW 101L or FW 238) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

IBIO480.name: Epigenetics
IBIO480.description: Molecular mechanisms of epigenetic modifications of eukaryotic genomes and their roles in biological processes, human diseases and cancer, plant development, and production.

IBIO483.name: Environmental Physiology (W)
IBIO483.description: Aspects of physiology important to the environmental relations of vertebrates and invertebrates
IBIO483.prerequisite: ((BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement) and (BS 162 or LB 144 or BS 182H) and (CEM 141 or CEM 151 or CEM 181H or LB 171)

IBIO485.name: Tropical Biology
IBIO485.description: Tropical biota emphasizing evolutionary and ecological principles compared across tropical ecosystems.
IBIO485.prerequisite: (IBIO 355) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

IBIO489.name: Seminar in Zoo and Aquarium Science
IBIO489.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
IBIO489.description: Scientific writing and oral presentations related to zoo and aquarium studies.

IBIO490.name: Overseas Study in Zoology
IBIO490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
IBIO490.description: Topical problems course in Zoology or coordinated by Zoology faculty in foreign countries.
IBIO490.prerequisite: (BS 162 or LB 144 or BS 182H) and (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H)
IBIO490.restrictions: Open to seniors or graduate students. Approval of department.

IBIO492.name: Interdisciplinary Studies in Conservation Medicine
IBIO492.description: Interdisciplinary studies focused on "health" as defined by the interactions of animal health, ecosystem health, and human health, viewed through the lens of human culture in an off-campus, multicultural setting.
IBIO492.prerequisite: (BS 161 and BS 162) or (BS 181H and BS 182H) or (LB 144 and LB 145)

IBIO492L.name: Advanced Research Applications in Conservation Medicine
IBIO492L.description: Field and laboratory techniques for assessing and monitoring biodiversity and health of humans, animals, and ecosystems in an off-campus, multicultural setting. Tools and techniques will be drawn from ecology, microbiology, molecular biology, genetics, histopathology, bioinformatics and statistics.
IBIO492L.prerequisite: (BS 161 and BS 162) or (BS 181H and BS 182H) or (LB 144 and LB 145)

IBIO493.name: International Communications in Conservation Medicine (W)
IBIO493.description: Development of communication skills (written and oral) to convey scientific information to scientists, health professionals, general public, and indigenous communities.
IBIO493.prerequisite: ((BS 161 and BS 162) and completion of Tier I writing requirement) or ((BS 181H and BS 182H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement) or ((LB 144 and LB 145) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

IBIO494.name: Independent Study
IBIO494.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
IBIO494.description: Supervised research on a topic not normally covered in the classroom.

IBIO495.name: Undergraduate Seminar
IBIO495.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
IBIO495.description: Economic, social and environmental impact of current developments in Zoology.
IBIO495.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Zoology Major.

IBIO496.name: Internship in Zoology
IBIO496.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
IBIO496.description: Practical experience applying zoology training in a setting outside the University.
IBIO496.restrictions: Open to seniors. Approval of department.

IBIO497.name: International Internship in Zoo and Aquarium Science
IBIO497.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
IBIO497.description: Application of zoological experience in a zoo or aquarium setting outside the United States.
IBIO497.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students. Approval of department; application required. A student may earn a maximum of 8 credits IBIO 496, IBIO 497, IBIO 498

IBIO498.name: Internship in Zoo and Aquarium Science
IBIO498.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
IBIO498.description: Application of zoological experience in a zoo or aquarium setting outside the university.
IBIO498.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors. Approval of department.

IBIO801.name: Professional Development
IBIO801.description: Ethical conduct in research. Selecting research topics and approaches. Scientific writing, grantsmanship, and publication. Career paths inside and outside academia.
IBIO801.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Integrative Biology.

IBIO804.name: Molecular and Developmental Neurobiology
IBIO804.description: Nervous system specific gene transcription and translation. Maturation, degeneration, plasticity, and repair in the nervous system.
IBIO804.restrictions: Open to graduate students in Neuroscience major.

IBIO805.name: Animal Welfare Assessment
IBIO805.description: Multidisciplinary online computer-based instruction in animal welfare science and related issues including physiology, behavior, human-animal interactions, suffering and pain, ethics, health, assessment and standards, and economics.

IBIO822.name: Topics in Ethology and Behavioral Ecology
IBIO822.description: Critical analysis through seminar-discussions of the primary research literature.

IBIO824.name: Stable Isotope Biogeochemistry
IBIO824.description: Principles of stable isotope chemistry applied to biogeochemical problems

IBIO826.name: Tropical Biology: An Ecological Approach
IBIO826.description: Principles of tropical ecology at the population, community, and ecosystem levels. Given at various sites in Costa Rica by the Organization for Tropical Studies.

IBIO827.name: Physiology and Pharmacology of Excitable Cells
IBIO827.description: Function of neurons and muscle at the cellular level
IBIO827.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Natural Science or in the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology or approval of department.

IBIO828.name: Molecular Ecology and Conservation Genetics
IBIO828.description: Population and evolutionary genetic principles applied to ecology, conservation, and management of fish and wildlife at the individual, population, and species level.

IBIO830.name: Statistical Methods in Ecology and Evolution I
IBIO830.description: Fundamental elements of data analysis in ecology and evolution. Programming fundamentals in the R computing language. Introduction to modeling biological data with modern methods for estimation and inference.
IBIO830.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Entomology or in the Ecology, Evolutionary Biology and Behavior Specialization or in the Ecology, Evolutionary Biology and Behavior Major or approval of department.

IBIO831.name: Statistical Methods in Ecology and Evolution II
IBIO831.description: Advanced interpretation and modeling of biological data with modern methods for estimation and inference using the R computing language.
IBIO831.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Entomology or in the Ecology, Evolutionary Biology and Behavior Specialization or in the Ecology, Evolutionary Biology and Behavior Major or approval of department.

IBIO832.name: Evolution of Nervous Systems
IBIO832.description: Evolutionary origins, mechanisms, and consequences of evolutionary change in nervous systems.
IBIO832.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering or in the Department of Integrative Biology or in the Program in Neuroscience or in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

IBIO839.name: Systems Neuroscience
IBIO839.description: Anatomy, pharmacology, and physiology of multicellular neural systems. Sensory, motor, autonomic, and chemo-regulatory systems in vertebrate brains.
IBIO839.restrictions: Open to graduate students or human medicine students or osteopathic medicine students in the College of Natural Science or in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or in the College of Human Medicine or in the College of Osteopathic Medicine or in the College of Social Science or in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

IBIO845.name: Multi-disciplinary Research Methods for the Study of Evolution
IBIO845.description: Techniques for engaging in multi-disciplinary research collaborations, including biology, computer science, and engineering. Students engage in group projects to answer fundamental questions about the dynamics of actively evolving systems including both natural and computational. Multi-disciplinary teams will learn to overcome discipline-specific language and conceptual issues. Experimental design, statistical analysis, data visualization, and paper and grant writing for multi-disciplinary audiences.

IBIO849.name: Evolutionary Biology
IBIO849.description: Major conceptual, theoretical and empirical questions in evolutionary biology. Readings and lectures are synthesized in student discussions and papers.

IBIO855.name: Molecular Evolution: Principles and Techniques
IBIO855.description: Current techniques used to characterize and compare genes and genomes. Genetic variation, assays of variation. Data analysis and computer use to conduct a phylogenetic analysis to compare organisms and infer relationships.

IBIO860.name: Modern Statistical Models in Ecology
IBIO860.description: Analysis of population and community dynamics with an emphasis on practical applications including model development and open source statistical programs.

IBIO863.name: Wildlife Disease Ecology
IBIO863.description: Role of wildlife disease in ecological interactions, factors underlying pathogen emergence, mathematical modeling of infectious diseases, conservation medicine.

IBIO867.name: Nature and Practice of Cognitive Science
IBIO867.description: Survey of how different disciplines explore the cognitive processes underlying intelligent behavior.

IBIO890.name: Special Problems
IBIO890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

IBIO891.name: Current Topics in Ecology and Evolution
IBIO891.description: Presentation and critical evaluation of theoretical and empirical developments in ecology and evolutionary biology by visiting scientists.

IBIO895.name: Seminar
IBIO895.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
IBIO895.description: Graduate seminar on current research topics in Zoology.

IBIO896.name: Population and Community Ecology
IBIO896.description: Population dynamics of animals and plants utilizing life tables and projection matrices. Species interaction. Life history theory. Structure and dynamics of communities. Succession.

IBIO897.name: Ecosystem Ecology and Global Change
IBIO897.description: Structure and function of natural ecosystems and their responses to global environmental change. Biogeochemical cycles, food webs, energy flow, nutrient cycling, and ecosystem management and restoration.

IBIO898.name: Population and Community Ecology Theory Laboratory
IBIO898.description: Practical experience designing and analyzing mathematical models in ecology from single species to communities, food webs and ecosystems.

IBIO899.name: Master's Thesis Research
IBIO899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

IBIO999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
IBIO999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
